head.s: Prepare for Knee Arthroscopy Surgery ( Teens )

p.s: When teens have to have knee surgery , they often need to have an arthroscopy .
An arthroscopy is a surgical procedure that uses a small camera and small instruments to see inside a joint ( the knee in this case ) and fix any problems .

( It 's Latin ,
arthro
meaning " joint " , and
scopy
meaning " see inside " ) .
A knee arthroscopy is one of the most common surgical procedures , even for teens .

item.s: Find out what your pre-op instructions are .
You might have to stop taking medications such as NSAIDs up to two weeks before your surgery .
You will also want to know how long before your procedure you must fast .
It is often from midnight the night before surgery on , but there are exceptions , so be sure to go over this with your surgeon .

figure.rend: Prepare for Knee Arthroscopy Surgery (Teens) Step 1.jpg

item.s: Find out what you may need to get ready for post-op .

This may include a brace/immobilizer , an ice machine/ice packs , pillows and blankets for comfort in the car on the way home from the hospital , or a prescription for pain meds ( some surgeons will give you the prescription ahead of time , others will only give it on the day of surgery ) .

figure.rend: Prepare for Knee Arthroscopy Surgery (Teens) Step 2.jpg

item.s: Gather all the items that you find out you need from the previous step .

figure.rend: Prepare for Knee Arthroscopy Surgery (Teens) Step 3.jpg

item.s: Take time off work/school if needed .
If you are in school , try to get your homework ahead of time so you can do it before your surgery .

If you ca n't do this for one reason or another ( such as surgery being booked for the next day , it does happen ) , try to email your teachers at least , and this way they will hopefully give you an extension on the work being done on your surgery day , and potentially for a few days after your surgery ( in case you need to stay out of town overnight , or are in too much pain to go back the day after ) .

figure.rend: Prepare for Knee Arthroscopy Surgery (Teens) Step 4.jpg

item.s: If needed , book a hotel .

Especially in rural areas , there may not be an orthopaedic surgeon in your town/city , so you may have to stay in a hotel before and/or after your surgery , especially if you need to have a drain removed the morning after surgery .
Make sure to ask for a medical rate , as many hotels offer discounts for medical appointment-related stays .

figure.rend: Prepare for Knee Arthroscopy Surgery (Teens) Step 5.jpg

item.s: Make sure you know all of your pre-op instructions .
If you are to discontinue the use of some medications , this is especially important .
You also need to know when to stop eating and drinking the night before surgery .

figure.rend: Prepare for Knee Arthroscopy Surgery (Teens) Step 6.jpg

item.s: Ensure you have all of the post op supplies discussed above .

figure.rend: Prepare for Knee Arthroscopy Surgery (Teens) Step 7.jpg

item.s: Eat a good dinner , and have a big snack , along with lots to drink .
You wo n't be able to eat or drink after midnight ( with exceptions ) on this night , so make sure you are well-fed , and well-hydrated .

figure.rend: Prepare for Knee Arthroscopy Surgery (Teens) Step 8.jpg

item.s: Make sure you follow your NPO , or Nil Per Oral instructions .
This means no food or drink after a set time , usually midnight .
Should you not follow your NPO directions , you may not be able to have your procedure done .

figure.rend: Prepare for Knee Arthroscopy Surgery (Teens) Step 9.jpg

item.s: Have everything ready for the next morning , such as clothes , toiletries , entertainment etc.

figure.rend: Prepare for Knee Arthroscopy Surgery (Teens) Step 10.jpg

item.s: Get a good night 's sleep .
Even though you will be " sleeping " with the anaesthesia the next day , you do n't get rest with anaesthesia , so you still need to get a good sleep .

figure.rend: Prepare for Knee Arthroscopy Surgery (Teens) Step 11.jpg

item.s: Stay NPO .
This is for your safety , as you do n't want to choke on your stomach contents while under general anaesthesia .

figure.rend: Prepare for Knee Arthroscopy Surgery (Teens) Step 12.jpg

item.s: Remember , if you eat or drink , your surgery may be cancelled .
Wear loose , comfy clothes .

It helps to wear short , baggy shorts , or loose pyjama-type bottoms , as if you need a drain after surgery , this will make it easy to get your bottoms over the drain , and also the bulky dressing that will be on your knee after surgery . You may also have a knee immobilizer , which , again , is quite bulky .

figure.rend: Prepare for Knee Arthroscopy Surgery (Teens) Step 13.jpg

item.s: Make sure you show up on time .
If you do n't , you will have to wait even longer to get your knee fixed .

figure.rend: Prepare for Knee Arthroscopy Surgery (Teens) Step 14.jpg

item.s: Be ready to wait .
Bring entertainment such as a phone or tablet , so you have something to do while you wait .

figure.rend: Prepare for Knee Arthroscopy Surgery (Teens) Step 15.jpg

item.s: Prepare yourself for discomfort .
After surgery , you will fell very tired , hungry and thirsty , and maybe a bit nauseous .
You will also likely be in quite a bit of pain , and you may have a drain in your knee to drain excess blood and fluid from your knee .
This will be removed about 18-36 hours after your surgery .

figure.rend: Prepare for Knee Arthroscopy Surgery (Teens) Step 16.jpg

item.s: Make sure you follow any and all post-op instructions , such a as physiotherapy , weight-bearing restrictions and bracing/wrapping .
Your surgeon should tell you or your parents all of this information .

figure.rend: Prepare for Knee Arthroscopy Surgery (Teens) Step 17.jpg

item.s: You may not sleep much the night after your surgery , as you may be in quite a bit of pain .
This is a good night to stay up and watch TV !
If possible , ice your knee after surgery .
Not only will the cold help with swelling , but also with pain .
An automatic icing machine , or " cryocuff " , while expensive , can be a worthwhile investment to simplify the post-op icing process .
If you 're prescribed pain medication , take it on schedule , even if you are not in pain .
It is better to be “ ahead ” of the pain than try to “ catch up ” .
After a few days , you will want to start weaning off the prescription medication and onto an over the counter drug , such as Advil or Tylenol .
You may not be able to use all the timing suggestions in this article , sometimes you are only given a few days to prepare .
You can still use all the information , just in a different time frame .
